title: About Me

title: Oliver Brown
text: Hi, I’m Oliver! I’m a first-year graduate student in the ScM Biostatistics program at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health.

I’m an avid reader (I’m currently reading 2666 by Roberto Bolaño), and movie watcher (my favorite is Blue Velvet dir. David Lynch). I also enjoy exploring the city, trying new cafes, and playing tennis.

title: Example Analysis: Palmer Penguins
text: This page demonstrates a complete data analysis workflow, from data loading and wrangling to visualization and summary.

title: Example Analysis: Palmer Penguins
text:
1. Introduction

The Question
How do physical measurements, specifically bill length, flipper length, and body mass, differ across the three penguin species (Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo)? Can these measurements be used to distinguish the species?


The Audience
This analysis is intended for aspiring data analysts or biology students new to R. It serves as a simple, reproducible example of a data exploration workflow using the tidyverse and palmerpenguins packages.


The Data

title: Example Analysis: Palmer Penguins
section: The data comes from the palmerpenguins R package [@Gorman2014]. This package contains data for 344 penguins collected from three islands in the Palmer Archipelago, Antarctica.
text: The data comes from the palmerpenguins R package [@Gorman2014]. This package contains data for 344 penguins collected from three islands in the Palmer Archipelago, Antarctica.

title: Example Analysis: Palmer Penguins
text:
2. Data Setup and Wrangling

Data Dictionary
First, let’s load the data and inspect the variables we’ll be using.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(palmerpenguins)

# Set a consistent theme for all plots
theme_set(theme_minimal())
